question: Question_B_06_(c)
statement:
Consider the triangle \emph{T} in three dimensions with vertices
\emph{(0, 1, 2)}, \emph{(1, 1, 5)} and \emph{(â1, 2, 2)}.

Consider also the plane \emph{P} that contains \emph{T}.

Write an equation for \emph{P} in the form

\begin{align*}x + by + cz = d\end{align*}

with \emph{b}, \emph{c} and \emph{d} to be determined.
sols:
First pick a known vector on \emph{P}. A convenient choice will be
\emph{(0, 1, 2)} (other vertices will work too).

Let \emph{(x, y, z)} be an arbitrary vector on \emph{P} (this represents
all possible vectors on \emph{P}, drawn with tail at origin and head on
\emph{P}), then the difference \emph{(x, y, z) - (0, 1, 2)} gives a
vector lying in \emph{P}.

This vector must then be perpendicular to the normal vector, which gives
the equation:

\begin{align*}[(x, y, z) - (0, 1, 2)] \cdot (-3, -3, 1) = 0\end{align*}

So

\begin{align*}-3x - 3y + z = (0, 1, 2) \cdot (-3, -3, 1) = -1\end{align*}

Dividing both sides by $-3$ gives
$b = 1, c = -\frac{1}{3}, d = \frac{1}{3}$
hints:
There are three unknowns and we know 3 vectors on \emph{P}, so plugging
them in will give a 3 by 3 linear system that can be solved by Gaussian
elimination.

However, this is not an efficient method. We know from part (b) that
vectors lying in the plane \emph{P} (meaning we can draw the heads and
tails both in \emph{P}) should all be perpendicular to the normal
vector. Use this information to define an equation using dot product.
